comments.commentBody: Isn't it ironic, now that the election is over and some of his fellow Texans want to secede, Rick Perry is against secession?

It just shows what money can buy. I think that Romney felt so entitled because he was so smart that he was able to start his career on a shoe-string (and probably his daddy's Rolodex), and get relatively rich, all by himself.

He was willing to spend so much money keeping alive his campaign org from 2008, that he was able to outmaneuver all the values candidates they could throw at him.

I think the GOP gave him the nomination out of sheer exhaustion.

God knows what they'll throw up in 2016.
Yeah but Mr. Huntsman actually tried to work with the Dems to make the world a better place.  Tainted fruit to the Repubs.

Romney bemoans the 47% who would never vote for him as those who feel entitled to gov't handouts, support and expect it. Shall we flip the wig? Romney came off as a person who felt far more entitled than most, come from a rich family, go to private schools, bully kids who weren't like you and got away with it. Entitled to conduct cruelty to animals without an ounce of remorse. Entitled to use his religion as an exuse to avoid the draft but at the same time protest in favor of the war in Vietnam.
Republicans entitled to keeping more of what they earn, after paying lobbyists millions to support legislation to create loopholes so they may save millions in taxes.
The GOP feels entitled to tell a woman what to do in regard to her own reproductive rights.
Now I ask you, who are the one who feel more entitled, the very rich, or the poor, underprivaliged & homeless. Entitled to lower taxes so they don't have to subsidize the 47%.
The scariest part is that Mitt Romney was the choice over Huntsman a man with a brain, Romney's brain went down the drain decades ago. When he never realized he's not so special. He was a terrible candidate, Shall we think Santorum or Herman Cain would have been better, Or perhaps serial adulter Newwt Gingrich ? Or Rick Perry, brain dead if there ever was a perfect example.
The GOP has light years to travel to find a worthy republican not full of old rhetoric, and they have to accomplish it at the speed of sound before the debt ceiling crisis destroys them

Very well said. Pres. Obama admitted time and again that his performance in the first debate was poor, thus showing his responsibility, integrity and courage. Later he made fun of that performance too ("after taking that long nap"...), and his intelligent, self-deprecating humor made him all the more endearing to us. Republicans just seem genuinely unable to understand that millions of people actually *like* Mr. Obama, just like him as the person he is, regardless of any "gifts".

If President Obama had responded similarly after his first debate performance and its reception, he would have had a much more difficult time winning the election, I think.  And that he didn't respond similarly reflects part of what made him, for me, a superior candidate for the office.

John,

Your link is not working. Here is what you really wanted:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=49xzZkepaGY

Lovely song, thank you.
Don't think Kolkata will be missing the author a lot either.

T this is the one  Hindu festival which brings  all Hindu Casts into one cast where people celebarte this festival by worshing gods for money , lighting earthen lamps, playing with fire crakers on the streets of India , eating sweets and playing teen pati.

The economic sclerosis of Kolkata some time back but people were enamoured by the "intellectual traditions". It is not easy to come to terms with reality of stagnation. Having said that Mumbai is not exactly the model.
The economic growth model currently pursued and pushed is unlikely to lead to more stable communities, equitable democracy, and sustainable economy in the long-run. So what happens to the millions who still live and work in Kolkata?

Yes, very much in the Bengali tradition -- this refusal to give back to Kolkata what he extracted at public subsidy. His counterparts in Mumbai, Chennai and most of those other towns will refuse to go away and live on the margins of other societies, but the Bengali, ever the ape, will not mind losing his soul on the streets of alien cities. The situation hasn't changed much, as evident from Sambuddha's lamentation. Educated Bengalis like Sambuddha chase jobs, never create them. Having lived away from Kolkata for more than a dozen years now, I marvel at the city's passion for life and its refusal to compromise its values at the altar of St. Market. It's still a city where a hundred thousand come out on the streets to mourn the death of a poet -- as they did last month when Sunil Gangopadhyay passed away. Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore,Pune all seem so soulless in comparison  --their denizens remind me of amoeba. Not one paisa is made the honest way in Delhi, which is also India's "rape capital" for the hilarity with which its people greet the daily reportage on degradation of women in its grotesque newspapers. Mumbai is the world's most expensive slum whose people remind me of worker ants. Bangalore? Dubai? Less said the better. What can you say about the former after its people managed to change is climate (not weather, climate) in less than a generation? And we are still waiting to see a museum and a public library to come up in Dubai.

Anne:

Mother was the Mother for all - especially for the numerous people she helped and loved unconditionally. There is no politics in pure humanity, that I called divinity.

The so called "myth of Mother Teresa" is a myth, created by people who did not know her or her work. I am from Calcutta/Kolkata and I do not subscribe to any question(s) about Her contributions to the humanity, which happened to highlight Calcutta at that time.

Questioning or politicizing Mother's work is not acceptable in my opinion. In the same way I do appreciate the numerous others who also selflessly serve to the humanity.

Congress party had a tacit agreement with Modi in GJ.
This angered Owaisi.
If you really need Gandhi tag, hire Sonia Gandhi as President of India (e.g. Queen Victoria in UK)

Resurgence? under Mamata Banerjee, huh? I would love to be optimistic, but don't you think this is going a bit too far?! Mamata's politics is a  bit like CPI-M in the 1970's. Bengal is about to enter another period of long decline. It won't be costly for educated middle class Bengalis in Calcutta, who can easily migrate to other Indian cities for jobs, but it would be very costly for the vast majority of Bengali people.

Your article intrigued me and made for good reading, but I do not entirely agree with you. The exodus you mention, "Of our 120 high school classmates on Facebook, nearly two-thirds do not live in Kolkata", takes place in cities like Delhi and Mumbai too. It happened to my classmates from school and college in Delhi too (mostly to the US). The other day I heard someone from Mumbai talk about a similar phenomenon for Mumbai too. We grew up on a diet of MTV and Star and that defined our aspirations.

I think cities go through cycles of growth and stagnation and it is possible to revive them. Delhi is a classic example. A decade ago, Biharis were probably saying the same thing about Patna; now it's another story, or so I am told.

And after having heard from and read the other side of the debate (about how Kolkata's resurgence is around the corner - drawing upon everything from films and literature to nouvelle Bengali cuisine (!) and the struggling IT industry), I remain a fence sitter. I think the the real question, and frankly the one that matters to me, is: will Kolkata be able to to reinvent itself?

The caption of Rabindranath Tagore's picture identifies him as a "Hindu poet". This is not only a curious way of describing a poet who transcended religious borders, but also factually incorrect. Tagore, loved in both Bengals alike, followed Brahmoism, a reform movement that broke away from Hinduism.
Also, it must be noted that Tagore had renounced his knighthood in the aftermath of Jalianwala Bagh Massacre of 1919. Although, it is debatable whether knighthood can be renounced, Tagore is not known to have referred to himself as "Sir" Rabindranath.

The article is clichéd & stereotype at the best! Not defending our city for it’s fault, but the parameters of development as notched up by the author probably fed by the “modern” gurus of management and development is simply reflection of lack of self analysis and lack of ability to reflect into future! Urbanization is not a sign of development, too many flyovers only reflects lack of far sighted planning for mass rapid local transport, consuming lot more is not a sustainable way of life… Kolkata and Bengal needs a 2nd renaissance but not on the parameters set by the clichéd parameters of growth and development that author is showing! Probably we, I mean you and me, who has somehow stuck to Kolkata needs to show more courage in not falling for the fad

No part of India can claim itself to have moved out of 3rd world tag, but atleast thanx God there a lot many people who have grown intellectually to think beyond communal mindset like yours which can produce only sterotype comments!

Hilarious. This post takes the cake!

When you said you find peace in Kolkata did you notice that there are still people, I mean Human Beings in Kolkata who pull rickshaws for a living? Do you know, that person can be replaced by a Internal Combustion Engine invented in the 18th century and widely available all around Kolkata. But he is still pulling a rickshaw for a living, a kind of living that is obsolete all around the world except for in Kolkata? What does it tells you about his dignity of life? Do you know there are dogs and cats that have a better living standard that that rickshaw puller? Obviously you will find peace in Kolkata because you are blind to the way of life of a rickshaw puller and you somehow find it acceptable. The difference is I don't, I think he could have had a better life for himself and his children only if Bengal has a better governance and policies to govern itself. So spare us your sob stories about about consumerist America.

Is Calcutta really the most attractive place in the world? Really, let's be objective here—it is a Bangladeshi refugee camp and has one of the most miserable records of human dignity anywhere on the planet. It is unfortunate that because you have a support system and the means to shield yourself from the outside world. Like most wealthy Indians, it is unlikely you have ever gone outside and walked the streets outside of an AC driven Innova. Go take a walk for a few km's then come back and let's see if you still fee the same way.

@esha4566
It seems that first two comments to your post were meant to insult, rather than for an objective and constructive analysis.

No matter what outsiders think of the flaws of Calcutta - and there are many - these armchair critics who do not live there, have no obligation or interest there but they do jump in the front to make caustic comments.

These critics forget that a huge majority do and in many case HAVE to live in Calcutta. There are also many Calcuttans who are also trying.

There is absolutely no USE for people such as these critics. To this reader this forum is ALSO to present constructive comments and NOT just comments that are simply meant to be poisonous.

I do agree that there are some regressions...but this is NOT REALLY right...I have lived in USA...for last 10 years...I have done my undergraduate studies here, worked here and now doing the graduate studies...literally this is not not true..still Kolkata is the most attractive place in the world for me, the most comfortable and peaceful place...it has also got a vibrant night life..Kolkata may have not developed the way Delhi have or may be Bangalore...which is related to politics totally...I guess your mother is right...just one year in America has pulled you out of your roots...I feel sorry for you !!

"Ireland reforms its medieval thinking and begins to respect women as full human beings, able to make their own decisions on their medical care, including abortion."

Alas, until Ireland separates it's laws from the Catholic church, that won't happen, as the church does not view women as full human beings.

Elvis,

Citations RE cleft palette, etc?

Of course not....

My deepest, deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Dr. Halappanavar. Although I did not know Dr. Halappanavar, I am very much saddened by her unfortunate and unnecessary death. Looking at her photo, I have to think that had we known each other, we would have been friends.
That any woman should be treated so barbarously and so callously in the 21st Century never fails to shock. The only solace anyone can take from this killing (I don't know of any other word to describe what happened), is that Ireland reforms its medieval thinking and begins to respect women as full human beings, able to make their own decisions on their medical care, including abortion.
I also hope all the right wing fanatics in this country, the panderers to the right wing and those disinterested voters who allow them to remain in office, learn of this story and give serious thought to the very real consequences of their wanting to strip away from women the right to control their own medical decisions. Yes, as this horrible story proves beyond a doubt, women will die if abortion is made legally unavailable to them.

"Dysfunctional political culture" - pretty much sums up everything that is wrong with West Bengal. Talented people, interesting culture, dysfunctional politics. Its strange - unlike  the badlands of North India, the dysfunctional political culture in Bengal doesn't arise from caste or caste violence - caste is hardly an issue in Bengal politics. However, North India seems to be finally emerging from the shadows and doing better, whereas West Bengal seems is sinking deeper into the morass. Bengalis are people who always say "The best days are behind us"!
Another example of a dysfunctional political culture.
Oh really. And who's going to save India from narrow-minded ignorant bigots like you?
Hopefully someone remembers to drive a stake through his heart!!
and in China, Peking University is not Beijing University, so there is still hope for Calcutta University remaining so!
I agree that changing names is silly - but it is happening all over India. That has nothing to do with Calcutta's decline.

Indians particularly Bengalis are satisfied with little things. They have no broad vision. They take pride in calling Calcutta-Kolkata,
Madras-Chinnai, Bombay-Mumbai. How stupid? They are changing history. These cities were world famous by their earlier names.
You open a business and create brand names. These brand names have value. That is what the company is worth. City names were brand names. Can you imagine McDonalds changing its name.
In USA most towns and cities are named after famous world cities.
In USA we have a town Called Delhi, a town called Egypt and many others. Indians need to spend their energies more fruitfully instead of changing names of cities and generally being against progress.
Nuclear agreement was signed and delivered several years ago and nothing has happened since. India needs to generate electric power today to improve the pathetic living standards of the poor masses.

It is certainly not the External Affairs Ministry's job to make sure Irish laws don't discriminate against members of other religious communities. That does't mean it cannot express concern or follow up on the death of an Indian citizen under unusual circumstances. Talking about Ireland's contribution to India's freedom struggle in this context is rather bizarre!

I fail to see the connection here. Savita was an Indian citizen in Ireland when she sought treatment. The question isn't what might have happened to her in India, but what did happen to her in Ireland as a result of outdated laws influenced too much by outdated religion.

No one is suggesting that Dr. Halappanavar should have gone back to India for treatment, at least I am not; nor am I saying that the Indian government should not have taken up the matter with the Irish. They should have. I was rather pleading for perspective. I was observing that India (in spite of some progress) has an unacceptably large number of maternal deaths. The 55,000 Indian women who die every year during childbirth are poor. Although many live in areas far from the centers of privilege, they are not nearly as far as Ireland. Yet, there are already more stories in the Indian media about this single death (of an upper-middle-class dentist) in a foreign land than there have been about all maternal deaths in India since its independence 65 years ago. That figure would likely top 5 million. Granted, such stories do attract media attention, but going overboard with them speaks not only to hypocrisy, not only to India's continuing class divide, but also to its longstanding culture of misogyny. Saying that does not to absolve Ireland's own culture of misogyny from possible complicity in this death
PS As for uninformed comments about my motivations (in particular that I'm Irish-American), let me suggest that "Selby" is an old Saxon name.

This certainly is very tragic.  It is well to express displeasure to the Irish authorities.  However, the Indian government should not  be unmindful that India has the highest maternal mortality of any country in the world.  Over 55,000 Indian women die in childbirth every year.  Some die because they lack transport and cannot get to a hospital in time, some die because the hospital lacks the capability, some die because the hospital is overcrowded, but all die in conditions that are unrelievedly grim and for reasons that are largely preventable.

I don't know too much about Mr. Gandhi, but a linguist colleague of mine visiting India during some elections last winter did observe that Mr. Gandhi was not very fluent in Hindi.  In fact, the colleague observed that there is a large and growing class of Indians in North India, all English educated, who are unable to communicate fluently in Hindi.  By contrast, ordinary people in the small towns of UP, most  without the benefit of an English education, could speak Hindi not only with the speed and fluency found among native speakers in any part of the world, but also with remarkable clarity and precision.

I'm not even going to cavil about the misspellings, but you sound like you're clearly in possession of all your marbles!

You should win some kind of prize for missing the point (in addition to bigotry), but here goes: the author (I think) was trying to point out that the CPM through cynically divisive electoral policies offered the carrot of agricultural reforms and populist rhetoric to poor farmers, but maintained their stronghold by beating the stick of doing absolutely nothing to increase productivity or develop the economy while actively disincentivizing real reform and keeping poor peasants poor.

Criticize bengalis all you want (and lord knows there's much to criticize), but the CPM by effectively destroying the economy, has not done much for the indolent, bourgeois "bhadralok" either. This in fact, is what the author is saying, not in as many words, that the bourgeois middle aged/middle class has mostly disappeared from the city, because there aren't any decent jobs for the middle class. Not even ones you get to be lazy at. Although honestly, I do part ways with him about the disappearing young to middle-aged middle class.

Not only is this simplistic, it's also steeped in the author's privilege of being from a certain economic and cultural background. I would like to see his plan for kolkata's economic renaissance, but I am practically certain that it would not be very progressive or pro-poor. The words "opening up the free market" would enter into it a lot.

What's wrong with worshiping mother Goddess and having a passive mentality? Aggression is as bad as laziness. When you eat up everything before you, then soon all you will be left with is piles of byproducts. Aggression has eaten up minerals, animals, humans - and left behind garbage and climate change. You must be a Rajput going by your surname. Your ancestors have mistreated lots of humans - millions and millions of humans, and even now you are too shortsighted to see where the world is going by your continuing mismanagement of Earth's resources.
